name: mitodetect-mitochondrial-variants
title: Mitochondrial Variant Detection
description: Comprehensive A-Z analysis pipeline for mitochondrial NGS data. Performs quality control, read mapping, variant calling, and heteroplasmy detection from next-generation sequencing of mitochondrial DNA. Essential for mitochondrial disease research and diagnostics. Samplesheet format: `detection,500X`
content:
MitoDetect - Mitochondrial Variant Detection

Comprehensive A-Z analysis pipeline for mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) sequencing data. Identifies variants, quantifies heteroplasmy levels, and performs quality control for next-generation sequencing of the mitochondrial genome.

What is Mitochondrial DNA Analysis?

Mitochondrial DNA is a small circular genome (~16.6 kb in humans) inherited maternally that encodes essential components of cellular energy production. Unlike nuclear DNA, cells can contain hundreds to thousands of mitochondrial genomes, each potentially carrying different variants - a phenomenon called heteroplasmy.

Key Features

  • Comprehensive QC: FastQC and MultiQC for read quality assessment
  • Variant Detection: Identify SNPs, indels, and structural variants in mtDNA
  • Heteroplasmy Quantification: Measure mixed populations of mitochondrial genomes
  • Ancient DNA Compatible: Handles degraded and low-input samples
  • High Sensitivity: Detect low-frequency variants down to 1-5% heteroplasmy
  • Automated Workflow: End-to-end analysis from raw reads to annotated variants

Pipeline Workflow

  1. Quality Control: Assess raw read quality with FastQC
  2. Read Trimming: Remove adapters and low-quality bases with fastp
  3. Reference Mapping: Align reads to mitochondrial reference genome
  4. Variant Calling: Identify variants with specialized mtDNA callers
  5. Heteroplasmy Detection: Quantify variant allele frequencies
  6. Annotation: Annotate variants with gene and pathogenicity information
  7. Reporting: Generate comprehensive MultiQC summary report

Scientific Applications

  • Mitochondrial Disease Diagnostics: Identify pathogenic mutations causing mitochondrial disorders
  • Cancer Research: Detect somatic mtDNA mutations in tumor samples
  • Population Genetics: Study mitochondrial haplogroups and human migration
  • Ancient DNA Studies: Analyze degraded mtDNA from archaeological samples
  • Aging Research: Track accumulation of mitochondrial mutations over time
  • Pharmacogenomics: Identify mtDNA variants affecting drug metabolism

Understanding Heteroplasmy

Heteroplasmy occurs when multiple mitochondrial DNA variants coexist within a cell, tissue, or individual. This is critical because:

  • Disease Threshold: Many mitochondrial diseases only manifest when pathogenic variants exceed 60-90% heteroplasmy
  • Tissue Specificity: Heteroplasmy levels vary between tissues, affecting clinical presentation
  • Inheritance Patterns: Heteroplasmy can shift dramatically between generations due to the mitochondrial bottleneck
  • Low-Level Variants: Even rare variants (<5%) may be clinically significant in some contexts

Input Requirements

  • Samplesheet (CSV): sample, fastq_1, fastq_2 columns
  • Sequencing Data: Paired-end or single-end FASTQ files
  • Target Enrichment: Works with whole-genome or mtDNA-enriched libraries
  • Coverage Requirements: Minimum 100X for basic variant detection, 500X+ recommended for low-level heteroplasmy

Main Outputs

  • Variant Calls: VCF files with all detected mitochondrial variants
  • Heteroplasmy Tables: Quantitative allele frequency measurements
  • Annotated Variants: Clinical significance and gene impact annotations
  • Coverage Plots: Per-base depth visualization across the mitochondrial genome
  • Quality Metrics: Comprehensive MultiQC report with alignment and variant statistics
  • Haplogroup Assignment: Mitochondrial lineage classification

Mitochondrial Disease Context

Mitochondrial disorders affect 1 in 5,000 individuals and can present with diverse symptoms including:

  • Neurological disorders (seizures, ataxia, neuropathy)
  • Cardiac disease (cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias)
  • Muscle weakness and exercise intolerance
  • Diabetes and endocrine dysfunction
  • Vision and hearing loss
  • Multi-system involvement

MitoDetect enables precise diagnosis by identifying pathogenic variants and quantifying their heteroplasmy levels across the 37 mitochondrial genes.

Performance Expectations

  • Small dataset (1-5 samples, 100X coverage): 1-2 hours
  • Standard dataset (10-20 samples, 500X coverage): 3-6 hours
  • Large cohort (50+ samples): 8-12 hours
  • High-depth ancient DNA: Variable, depends on coverage and sample preservation

Quality Control Metrics

  • Read Quality: Per-base sequence quality, GC content, adapter contamination
  • Mapping Statistics: mtDNA vs nuclear DNA ratio, mapping efficiency
  • Coverage Uniformity: Even coverage across the circular mitochondrial genome
  • Strand Bias: Detection of technical artifacts in variant calling
  • Heteroplasmy Confidence: Statistical support for low-frequency variants

Perfect for: Mitochondrial Disease Diagnostics • Cancer Research • Population Genetics • Ancient DNA • Aging Studies • Clinical Sequencing
